text:
[Urgent] This has probably been asked already but can someone share how I can track clicks from internal links? Example: Page A has a link to the Demo page. I want to track how many folks clicks on the “Demo page” link on Page A.

Please please tell me the easiest solution; GTM click triggers and anything complicated is out of question (campaign goes live tomorrow). TIA! :pray:

text:
Not sure if I’m missing anything here..but if you’re directing users to the demo page using the CTA, then adding UTM params can work?

If it’s for A/B testing, then add different UTM params for different pages or placements..

GA can show how many users ended on your demo page using the CTA on page A..

attachments.text: Google's John Mueller said in a webmaster hangout on YouTube yesterday at the 16:56 mark into the video that it can confuse Google if you are tagging your internal links with tracking parameters, such

text:
Don't use UTMs on internal links. This is a bad practice. Usually it leads to double counting page views.

To know the number of clicks you should either tag in GTM or tag with something else. The easiest tool for tagging is the Facebook tracking (there is a setup wizard). Either way, I highly recommend you get someone to tag this for you in GTM. It is literally a 5 min job and everything else is a workaround.

elements.text:

text: <@U012GHRAHDK>  Agree with Illiya. The best thing to do this is set up event tracking with GTM. Events can be set to track when a link is clicked on any place on the site and you can put in as much detail as you need about where they clicked. I'd be happy to help get it set up if you'd like (for free) with Google Tag Manager.

elements.text: Agree with Illiya. The best thing to do this is set up event tracking with GTM. Events can be set to track when a link is clicked on any place on the site and you can put in as much detail as you need about where they clicked. I'd be happy to help get it set up if you'd like (for free) with Google Tag Manager.

<@U012GHRAHDK> I have that same question actually! right now we are using GTM and im setting up individual tags / triggers for each link, so this means that only important clicks are getting tracked…. because it just takes too much time to track everything.

so, i also would like to know if there are better ways out there!

text:
<@U02GKTN1NDC> There is a better way. You can setup a tag in GTM that is triggered by internal link clicks that are only contained within certain elements on the website. For instance, if you only want to track the navigation links, you can identify the element that wraps the navigation and set the trigger in GA to only fire when an internal link is clicked within that element.

If you only want to fire on links that point to a specific page you can set a trigger to fire on Link Clicks that contain '/demo' for example.

This can be the same tag with different triggers that have different rules associated to them.

I'd be willing to do a video demo on how to make this happen in GTM if there is enough interest. But, this is a good article on how this works: <https://www.lupagedigital.com/blog/track-internal-links/>

elements.text:
There is a better way. You can setup a tag in GTM that is triggered by internal link clicks that are only contained within certain elements on the website. For instance, if you only want to track the navigation links, you can identify the element that wraps the navigation and set the trigger in GA to only fire when an internal link is clicked within that element.

If you only want to fire on links that point to a specific page you can set a trigger to fire on Link Clicks that contain '/demo' for example.

This can be the same tag with different triggers that have different rules associated to them.

I'd be willing to do a video demo on how to make this happen in GTM if there is enough interest. But, this is a good article on how this works:

text: <@U012GHRAHDK> I just realized you said GTM is not an option. Sorry about that - the only other option is putting a query string on the URLs like /?link=demo or something like that. That is the quickest way to do it if you have dev resources to update the links.

text:
In GA events you have 3 values you can populate: Category, Action and Labels. These can be populated with static or dynamic data (using variables) and pass pretty much anything you want.

You can also add a dimension on GA reports to show the page the event took place. For example, I track CTA events when folks click on my pricing page. Here is what the label of the CTA is and the page they clicked from:

elements.text:

text:
Buyer journeys are non-linear. You can have someone come to your site for the first time via an branded SEO blog (e.g., How does [company name] work?") and request a demo in the same visit. But that doesn't mean they didn't hear someone talk about you on a webinar and check you out on G2, before typing that query.

All that to say, you need content for all different types of intent and awareness stages. You'll get the most eyeballs with topical content, though branded and product content will drive the most handraisers.
